report_title: Commercial Cooking Equipment Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: The Commercial Cooking Equipment Manufacturing industry has grown, despite volatility in recent years. Through 2019, rising consumer spending, spurred by greater per capita disposable income and increased aggregate private investment, supported downstream demand. As consumers spent more on dining experiences, restaurants and other food-service companies invested in commercial cooking equipment to fulfill demand and adapt to the evolution of the restaurant industry. However, the COVID-19 pandemic injected volatility into the industry, as downstream demand dissipated in 2020 amidst widespread shutdown to stem the spread of the pandemic. Consumers have since returned to restaurants as the pandemic has abated,

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2020, the outbreak of the COVID-19 caused a decline in the overall economy and deterred businesses from making large capital purchases, resulting in decline in revenue for the industry. In particular, food-service establishments were forced to entirely close or switch to all takeout operations, which led to an uptick in sector bankruptcies. Frequently, closing food-service manufacturers sell the used commercial equipment to other sector manufacturers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Since the Pandemic Has Abated, Downstream Trends Have Normalized
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Restaurants and other end users of commercial cooking equipment ramp up their capital spending on cooking equipment to replace older models in disrepair, to construct new dining facilities or to comply with various safety and energy requirements during period of strong growth. Since 2021, rising per capita disposable income, increased aggregate private investment and rising demand from food services and drinking places has bolstered demand for commercial cooking equipment.
The expansion of American fast-food chains overseas has aided the industry as domestic manufacturers have won contracts to equip new kitchens abroad.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Commercial Cooking Equipment Manufacturers Will See Stable Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand for domestically manufactured products will rise alongside increased per capita disposable income and rising private capital investment from the downstream food-service sector as the economy grows. The food-service sector will grow modestly, and consumers will continue to allocate a sizeable chunk of their paychecks to dining out as concerns about the pandemic abate. Sustained growth in consumer spending levels will likely prompt downstream restaurant and hospitality industries to modestly increase investment in commercial cooking equipment.

The evolution of restaurant dining will fuel the industry's growth. In the United States, demand from food-services and drinking places is projected to rise. The development of new quick service and casual dining concepts, as well as the expansion of food-services into nontraditional locations, will to lead to the replacement and upgrade of existing cooking equipment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers Will Invest Heavily in Developing New Products
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Domestic manufacturers will shift their focus to research and development as companies compete globally to develop high-end commercial cooking equipment. According to the latest forecast by the National Restaurant Association, restaurant manufacturers are increasingly emphasizing equipment and fixtures that help save energy and water. In particular, manufacturers of quick service restaurants, which operate with low profit margins and require cost savings in all areas of operation, plan to purchase energy-saving kitchen equipment.

Like much of the manufacturing sector, companies in this industry have increased their capital spending to focus on automating their production lines. Nonetheless, the industry remains dependent on labor to manufacture commercial cooking equipment. Labor is required in the production process, as well as to market and sell products and provide post-sale installation and maintenance. Many production workers in the industry are highly skilled and perform functions that cannot be replaced by technology, like assembling complex parts and programming computerized systems.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures commercial cooking equipment for end customers, such as restaurants, hotels and military establishments. The industry manufactures products including coffee makers, fryers, microwaves, ovens and ranges, corn poppers, stoves, warmers, hot plates, steamers and water heaters. Enterprises that manufacture commercial dishwashers, refrigerators, laundry dryers and washing machines are not included in this industry.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - increasing

threats: Demand from food services and drinking places

key_trends: Manufacturers can charge premium prices for well-established products. However, less-expensive imports counteract producers' ability to extract the highest prices.
The COVID-19 pandemic injected volatility into the industry
New restaurant concepts in the United States and abroad will fuel demand moving forward
The largest manufacturers have expanded their portfolios via acquisitions
Leading firms have also used mergers and acquisitions to exert dominance across the supply chain
Manufacturers are subject to a range of environmental regulations
Larger companies can generate greater margins because of their marketing power

market_segmentation.segment_description: Dealers purchase cooking equipment directly from manufacturers and resell the equipment in showrooms to downstream consumers in hotel and restaurant industries.
Food-service distributors purchase the cooking equipment and distribute these products to various food institutions and restaurants.
Restaurants and food institutions encompass facilities that provide food for large quantities of people, not necessarily for profit.
Online retail outlets include manufacturers, wholesalers and intermediaries who market industry goods via the internet.
Other segments include specialty distributors, club stores and various buying groups.
Exports represent a growing final destination for commercial cooking equipment.

products_and_services.product_description: Cooking equipment includes commercial ranges, gas fryers, countertop fryers, countertop griddles, commercial ovens, microwave ovens, conveyor ovens and impinger ovens.
Equipment consists of holding cabinets, banquet carts, countertop food warmers, electric steam tables, proofing cabinets, drawer warmers and cold food tables.

Cooking equipment is sold at high margins and is among the largest, costliest and most essential purchases for restaurants. Some end markets may prefer gas-fired equipment due to more precise temperature control and more dispersed heat transfer.
Products in this segment include food preparation equipment, beverage dispensers and tabletop cooking equipment.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Capital expenditure of food service establishments
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This industry relies heavily on the capital expenditure of restaurant, hotel and food-service operators. When these establishments expand operations and invest in equipment, the industry grows.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Revenue from food services and drinking places
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Revenue generated from food services and drinking places is expected to decline in 2023, representing a potential threat to the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports have increased as a share of domestic demand as the value of the US dollar has increased, making imported goods relatively less expensive domestically.
Together, imports from Germany, Italy and the Netherlands comprise nearly half of all industry imports.

Commercial cooking equipment manufacturers in the United States benefit from their international reputation for having high-quality parts as mandated by strict production standards and industry regulation.

The higher prices of US-manufactured goods have hindered export growth, especially true as the increasing US dollar has made domestic products relatively more expensive abroad, deterring international markets. However, exports have surged to Uzbekistan in 2023, largely for reexport to Russia as the country attempts to circumnavigate Western restrictions.

business_locations.location_description: Sustained manufacturing activity across the Great Lakes has maintained concentration of companies in the region. Middleby, Dover and Illinois Tool Works, three of the industry's largest manufacturers, are headquartered in Illinois.

The geographic spread of companies is highly concentrated in the regions in which manufacturing infrastructure has long existed. The Southeast region holds one of the industry's largest players, Weltbild, which is headquartered in New Port Richey, FL.

California holds the most industry cooking equipment manufacturing establishments by a wide margin. California has a large manufacturing presence and significant downstream markets. Due to California's prominence, the West region is one of the largest regions in the country for commercial cookware manufacturing.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Federal legislation like the US Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act outlines federal laws and requirements pertaining to air quality standards, emissions discharges and the proper disposal of hazardous materials. The federal government has the power to enforce these standards and conduct audits through the EPA. The EPA also requires manufacturers to provide EnergyGuide information labels on all products to provide information pertaining to the energy consumption and operating costs associated with cooking appliances.

The federal government sets standards for workplace safety through OSHA. Federal regulations through OSHA include limits on chemical exposure during manufacturing, safety training and education requirements, provision of personal protective equipment and the ability to audit and levy fines for regulatory violations.

The NSF International, independent global public health organization that has voluntary compliance within the industry. NSF International sets standards throughout North American commercial food preparing industries to ensure cleanliness standards that go beyond state and federal requirements. Cleanliness standards consist of separate tiers, which apply to food-service equipment like kitchen, bakery, pantry and cafeteria units; commercial spray-type dishwashing and glass-washing machine racks; commercial cooking and hot food storage equipment; hot-water generating.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Low and steady industry assistance level.

basis_points.basis_description: Companies produce a variety of differentiated goods, competing on product features like design, brand recognition, reliability, durability, energy efficiency, price, after-sale service and timeliness of delivery.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Consolidation has risen as the largest players have merged
concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four players accounting for half of all revenue. The industry, once highly fragmented, has contracted over the past few decades as small-scale manufacturing operations slowly merged into larger companies.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large companies have leveraged their scale to maintain dominance
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger manufacturers have used their size to dominate the industry by integrating their value chains, opening warehouses and distribution centers to market and sell their own manufacturing wares. Over time, this strategy has enabled them to sell their products at extremely competitive prices compared with those offered by smaller producers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Represent the Largest Cost Category
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs are expected to account for 44.7% of revenue in 2023. Manufacturers use large amounts of raw materials and component parts, like stainless steel, aluminized steel, electrical components, rubber, plastic and hardware, to manufacture commercial cooking equipment.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Inputs are purchased from a broad range of suppliers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Inputs are purchased from a broad range of suppliers that are available in adequate quantities at competitive prices.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Increases in the price of steel or any other commodity
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Increases in the price of steel or any other commodity that the company cannot pass on to its customers can lead to lower profit margins, though most significant price increases can be passed on to customers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: DOMESTIC ECONOMIC CONDITIONS INFLUENCE DEMAND, INCLUDING SEASONALITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry draws customers for the downstream food-services sector, which limits year to year fluctuations. Regardless of economic conditions, the industry is highly seasonal and earns more revenue during the summer months. Downstream customers include the catering business, particularly schools, which tend to make most of their commercial cooking equipment purchases during summer months.

volatility_points.volatility_title: GLOBAL ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY DRIVES REVENUE TRENDS
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is sensitive to trends in both global economic conditions and exchange rates, since domestic companies rely on other countries' products in the production process. Likewise, the appreciation of the US dollar makes domestic goods more expensive for foreigners, leading to a decline in exports and a countervailing surge in lower-cost imports. Import competition from offshore manufactures that have moved plants offshore has contributed to volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: NEW PRODUCTS ARE KEY TO BRAND DOMINANCE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers produce a wide range of products, including primary cooking equipment like electric options. Manufacturers have increasingly focused on new electric equipment, which is more environmentally friendly than gas options.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports compete with our products on a cost basis due to their low wage costs. A sizable percentage of commercial cooking equipment is produced internationally, making it a very competitive atmosphere.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: We produce a diversified range of products including commercial cooking equipment; commercial food preparation machines; and other commercial containers requiring a high degree of cleanliness and sanitization.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The price of steel is subject to some volatility, often rising and falling in line with overall economic activity. Due to the high level of price volatility, it is difficult to price products in the long term.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Outsourcing manufacturing to low-cost regions greatly reduces wage costs. Consequently, companies have turned to low-wage labor to remain competitive in terms of price.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, such as RFID tags?
FAQs.answer: Automation has greatly enhanced manufacturing capacity and standardization of products. Specialized production components help to specialize our equipment for specific applications.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Automation has helped to curb wage costs for most of employees. However, companies hire highly specialized employees for products, who do require high levels of compensation.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Participation in industry assistance groups and seminars keeps manufacturers aware of industry news and changes. Additionally, investment in new processes and research helps to enhance efficiencies and adhere to legislation.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers implement standard operating procedures that must be followed on a daily basis. Additionally, companies conduct training sessions and offer courses to enhance workers' understanding of the processes and how they relate to their safety.

FAQs.question: How does input price volatility affect profit margins?
FAQs.answer: High volatility, coupled with high input prices negatively impacts profit margins. Consequently, due to the high price of inputs and the prevalence of low-cost imports, profit margins are negatively impacted by volatility.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Due to product and regional specialization, many customers stick with one brand. Custom-made products become a necessity for customers, and they subsequently depend on them for their reliability and familiarity with the brand.

FAQs.question: How automated are your production facilities? What capital upgrades do you have planned in the near future?
FAQs.answer: Automation reduces costs, particularly those associated with labor. US manufacturers experience relatively high labor costs compared with overseas manufacturers in less-developed countries. Automation can replace costly labor requirements with capital and equipment.

FAQs.question: How do you maximize your operating capacity to improve profit margins and cost of goods sold? Have you had difficult operating at optimum capacity in the past?
FAQs.answer: Companies that manufacture goods at a high capacity can derive low manufacturing costs per unit.

FAQs.question: Does the company provide after-sales advice to its customers? Does the company generate revenue through accessory sales?
FAQs.answer: Companies focus on attracting repeat buyers by offering additional services to customers after sales are completed. Customer service, repairs, and additional expertise are significant competitive factors in the industry.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is derived from export markets? Do your products face any direct competition from foreign-manufactured goods?
FAQs.answer: A rising US dollar makes domestically manufactured commercial cooking equipment less competitive abroad, while substitute imported commercial cooking equipment becomes more competitive domestically.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is derived from food service establishments? How do you compete for business from this industry?
FAQs.answer: This industry relies heavily on the capital expenditure of restaurant, hotel, and foodservice operators. Therefore, when foodservice establishments expand their operations and invest in equipment, the industry is poised for growth.

FAQs.question: Do you have any long-term contracts for the procurement of steel? How much of added input costs are you able to pass on to customers?
FAQs.answer: As the price of steel increases, the cost of manufacturing appliances rises, eroding companies' profit margins.
